text:
I grew up in Nigeria, where
we didn't have constant power.

But I see renewable energy
as the path to addressing

a lot of the issues that a lot
of emerging market countries
are facing, not just Nigeria.

Prior to HBS, I was a mechanical
engineer doing renewable energy

work, and I saw
more opportunities

to continue learning
and growing.

And so I pursued an option
in management consulting.

CareerLeader is the tool
that I used coming into HBS.

It really helped me
focus in on strategy

and showed that consulting was
a very good match for me because

of the specific motivating
factors and interests
that I had.

I first met my career coach
within the first few weeks
at HBS.
I shared my CareerLeader report.

A few items that came up
were, "Am I going to learn?"

Am I going to get the right
exposure and experience?

Am I going to be impactful, and
does it set me up for future
moves and success?"

I was surprised at the
breadth of resources at HBS.

And the ones that
surprised me the most

were the level of
engagement with students,

and also the professors
being willing to open up

their networks to students who
show any inkling of passion.

I've discovered that
you need more than just

your technical skills
as an engineer.

You also need the social
skills, the business skills,

to be able to take a project
from an idea to fruition.

And to assess if the full-time
offer was right for me,

I worked with a career
coach to reflect back

on the key items we
identified as experiences
I needed to get from the role.

And I could see myself engaging
with the right partners,

growing, and being part of a
bigger mission that's impactful.
Awesome, thank you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
